NOTE 
 
The fiscal year (FY) of the Government ends on 30 June. FY before a calendar 
year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2003 ends on 30 
June 2003. 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by T. Mellor, Pacific Operations Division.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Efforts to reform the Government’s financial information system in the Fiji Islands began 
in 1994 when the Ministry of Finance initiated the Accrual Accounting Project. The project was 
postponed due to implementation difficulties and was subsequently subsumed by the Financial 
Management Reform (FMR) Project in 1998. The FMR was supported by the New Zealand 
Agency for International Development,1 culminating in the preparation and enactment of the 
Public Finance Management Act (PFMA) of 1999. The FMR provides the Government with the 
conceptual and institutional framework to better implement its policies, and to deliver public 
goods and services more efficiently and effectively. The FMR is an important element of the 
public sector reform agenda. 
 
2.  The Government initiated parallel public administration and public enterprise reforms 
with the enactment of the Public Enterprise Act of 1996 and the Public Service Act of 1999. 
Implementation of these two pieces of legislation was supported with technical assistance (TA) 
from the Australian Agency for International Development and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB).2 After its enactment in March 1999, the PFMA was suspended in August 1999 following 
a change of government. ADB provided assistance to the then government to review the scope 
and implementation plan in late 1999. The review report emphasized the need to press ahead 
with a revised FMR, taking into account resource and capacity constraints as well as risk 
management  considerations.  Recognizing  the  urgency  of  proceeding  with  FMR,  the  newly 
elected Government in September 2001 approved a broad FMR implementation strategy. In 
view  of  limited  resources  and  the  lack  of  technical  expertise  within  the  public  sector,  the 
Government requested ADB’s assistance during the 2002 country programming mission to 
reactivate  the  implementation  of  the  PFMA.  The  Fact-Finding  Mission  was  undertaken  in 
February 2003. The TA3 framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Over the years, there has been increasing recognition by public officials of inefficient and 
ineffective public resource management. The main problem is that traditional public resource 
management focuses on inputs and compliance rather than achievement of outputs and results. 
Like most other public administration systems, the Fiji Islands’ administrative and financial 
management systems are designed to control the actions of ministers and public servants to 
ensure  compliance  with  rules,  procedures,  and  budget  appropriations,  and  ignore  the  key 
aspects of performance, accountability, and transparency. 
 
4.  Reforms  relating  to  the  public  enterprise  sector  and  public  administration  through 
implementation of the Public Enterprise Act of 1996 and the Public Service Act of 1999 have 
had some beneficial effects on other areas such as the recognition of performance and results, 
and enhanced disclosure of selected information in the annual budget papers. The suspension 
of the PFMA in 1999 created a disconnect between various elements of a sequenced set of 
reforms. The absence of strategic control of different aspects of the reform agenda by central 
agencies has also created some overlap of functions and unintended negative consequences of 
actions  at  the  working  level.  For  example,  the  Public  Service  Act  of  1999  requires  the

2 
establishment of a chief executive service. It also requires a chief executive to enter into a 
performance contract with the portfolio minister, who would hold the chief executive accountable 
for the performance of staff and the ministry as a whole, financially and administratively. This 
requirement was implemented in January 2003. However, it may be unreasonable to hold the 
chief executive fully accountable for performance and results without the support of an output-
based budget management system proposed under the PFMA, and without control over staff 
recruitment and dismissal. 
 
5.  The key objectives of the PFMA are to (i) improve the public financial management 
system of the State; and (ii) enhance the financial accountability of Parliament, the cabinet, 
ministers,  public  officers,  and  public  entities.  The  PFMA  addresses  all  major  financial 
management issues that are critical for sound fiscal policies and is seen as reflecting best 
practice  in  financial  and  economic  management  internationally.  The  more  controversial 
provisions  of  the  PFMA  relate  to  the  move  towards  performance  budgeting  and  accrual 
accounting, and the purchaser/provider arrangement between ministers and their agencies. 
Related provisions of the above concepts comprise a significant part of the Act. The passage of 
time  since the  drafting  of  the  PFMA,  and  lessons learned  in  the implementation  of  these 
principles in the Pacific and elsewhere in the world have raised concerns about their excessive 
complexity and sophistication, given the current state of fiscal management, and the availability 
of resources and skills in the Fiji Islands. 
 
6.  The  current  public  finance  management  system  defines  the  roles  of  Parliament, 
ministers, and public entities almost solely in terms of inputs, with its attendant emphasis on 
compliance with cash budget appropriations. The continuation of the current system unchanged 
is clearly inconsistent with the intent of FMR and with reforms in other parts of the public sector. 
On  the  other  hand,  many  of  the  provisions  of  the  suspended  PFMA  do  not  seem  to  be 
appropriate to the needs of the Fiji Islands at this time or in the foreseeable future, especially 
given the scarcity of resources and skills that are needed to implement such a comprehensive 
fiscal and financial management framework. 
 
7.  While  the Government  has  made  clear its commitment  to  improve  the  productivity, 
accountability, and transparency of public finance management, it also realizes that a strategic 
review of the components of its reform agenda is warranted, as is the need to take account of 
capacity building in terms of enhancing systems, management, accounting, and information 
technology skills to ensure successful implementation and sustainability of reforms over the 
longer term. The Government has sought assistance to reactivate the FMR Project based on 
global experience and lessons learned from the region. Specifically, assistance is needed to 
review the PFMA to assess its current adequacy and appropriateness for the Fiji Islands' 
circumstances and to establish a detailed action plan that will sequence and pace the major 
components of the financial management reform in a revised PFMA. 
 
8.  The  objectives  of  a  good  public  financial  management  system  are  to  ensure  the 
soundness of public finances; increase the efficiency and effectiveness of fiscal activities; and 
promote  transparency,  accountability,  and  legitimacy  in  government  financial  transactions. 
Properly designed and implemented, a good financial management system will result in a 
better-informed public debate about the objectives and results of the Government’s strategic 
policies and financial management, and make government and its institutions more accountable 
for  the  use  of  public  financial  resources.  The  Government’s  broad  FMR  provides  a  firm 
foundation, and success will depend on the effective implementation of a revised PFMA.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will support a review of the PFMA, taking into account resource and capacity 
constraints and the progress of reform activities in other areas of the public sector since the 
PFMA was enacted in early 1999, and will make recommendations for revised legislation. Upon 
the enactment of the bill, the emphasis of the TA will be on (i) improving fiscal management 
through  better  management  of  public  expenditure  and  revenue  to  achieve  desired  social 
outcomes, and (ii) enhancing government and managerial accountability through timely and 
comprehensive reporting of government finances.    
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The TA will finance the provision of consulting services to assist the Government in (i) 
reviewing the PFMA, and will make recommendations on major components of a revised bill; (ii) 
preparing a detailed implementation plan that focuses on government priorities, a realistic and 
sustainable timetable of system development, capacity building, and change management;  (iii) 
assisting the implementation steering committee, on an intermittent basis, to monitor progress 
and recommend corrective actions as appropriate, and (iv) providing specific technical advice to 
the Ministry of Finance and Planning and the steering committee. 
 
11.  The  key  outputs  of  the  TA  will  be  the  drafting  instructions  for  a  new  financial 
management bill to underpin FMR; and an implementation plan that should be realistic and 
achievable, taking into account the capacity and resource constraints of the Ministry of Finance 
and Planning and line agencies. In addition, the TA will provide training materials in public 
sector financial management that contain modern concepts and principles that are appropriate 
to the Fiji Islands’ circumstances and that achieve the Government's policy objectives. As the 
introduction of the FMR will require reorientation of public officials from inputs to a focus on 
performance and results, which requires a different approach to management and managerial 
accountability, it is important that the implementation plan remain flexible to take account of 
progress and unavoidable delays. Thus, the transfer of project management skills to a local 
counterpart will be critical to ensure sustainability of the plan. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be undertaken in two phases. Phase one will (i) assess the current status of 
public sector reform activities that would require immediate FMR actions to support these 
elements (for example, the need to reorient the budget to incorporate meaningful outputs and 
performance indicators to support the operation of the chief executives and senior executive 
services); (ii) review and prioritize the components of the suspended PFMA in accordance with 
government policy objectives and taking account of the skills and resource constraints of the 
Ministry of Finance and Planning and line agencies; (iii) recommend changes to the PFMA and 
other related legislation, as appropriate, for approval by the cabinet; (iv) prepare a detailed 
implementation  plan  with  specific  assessment  of  risk,  internal  and  external  resource 
requirements (human, systems, and training), and a realistic timetable for each component of 
the revised legislation; and (v) develop a change management and communication plan to 
ensure understanding, support, and commitment of stakeholders. 
 
13.  Phase two of the TA will start after the revised legislation is passed by Parliament, and 
will  involve  the  establishment  of  an  implementation  steering  committee  comprising  senior 
officials  of  central  agencies  (including  the  auditor  general’s  office) and  line  agencies.  The 
committee will be supported by a public financial management consultant who has technical

4 
expertise and project management experience in this area. As the implementation is expected 
to be long term (3–5 years), the consultant will be supported by a local counterpart who will be 
trained to take over the management of the project at the end of the term of the consultant’s 
contract  (expected to be within 24 months from TA commencement). The consultant, with the 
support of the financial management training specialist, will be responsible for the development 
of  technical  training  (in  public  expenditure  management,  performance-based  budget 
management, accounting and financial reporting, and internal control systems) based on the 
specific budgeting and financial information requirements of the revised PFMA, and will assist in 
the development of a “train-the-trainers” program. It is expected that the training program will be 
developed in conjunction with a local educational institution (for example the University of the 
South Pacific) to ensure that training will be ongoing and delivered during the transitional and 
post-implementation periods. The TA will also provide for short-term consulting services on 
specific technical components included in the implementation plan. 
 
14.  As the implementation will be spread over a 3-year period at a minimum, it is imperative 
that the Ministry of Finance and Planning and line agencies be committed to the process, so as 
to ensure, in particular, the availability and continuity of local counterparts to manage the 
implementation and to participate in training programs. In addition, government decisions on 
policies and funding needed for implementation should be adhered to, as far as practicable, to 
ensure that early gains are realized given the long lead time of implementation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at US$620,000 equivalent, of which US$460,000 is 
the foreign exchange cost and US$160,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. ADB will 
finance the total foreign exchange cost, and the Government will finance the local currency 
component. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government of Japan. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The Ministry of Finance and Planning will be the Executing Agency of the TA. An 
implementation  steering  committee  will  be  established  consisting  of  representatives  of  the 
Ministry  of  Finance  and  Planning,  the  Public  Service  Commission,  the  Prime  Minister’s 
Department, line agencies of large spending ministries (such as Health, Education, and Works), 
smaller ministries (such as Justice and Labor), and budget-dependent statutory agencies (such 
as the Ombudsman). The Audit Office should be a member of the implementation steering 
committee to ensure that it is aware of the implementation plan, in particular the transitional 
arrangements, and to provide feedback on departmental implementation especially where it 
may see difficulties of compliance with policy requirements, and where training is needed. 
 
17.  International consultants will be engaged by ADB as individuals in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  It is envisaged that one international consultant (lead 
consultant) with experience in public sector financial management reforms will be recruited, on 
an intermittent basis, for a total of 12 months. Other short-term consultants will be recruited on a 
needs basis for a total of 7 months: a trainer with public expenditure management knowledge 
and a system accountant with experience in software packages appropriate for public sector 
financial applications. The lead consultant will be responsible for the content and scope of 
training  materials  in  collaboration  with  a  local  educational  institution.  The  Government  will 
engage  the  local  educational  institution  to  collaborate  on  the  preparation  of  the  training 
materials, participate in the initial training, and take over training activities after the completion of

5 
the  TA.  The  Government  will  also  engage  a  domestic  consultant  in  accordance  with 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB who, with advice from the lead consultant, will develop a 
change  management  and  communication  strategy  to  ensure  that  all  public  officials  fully 
understand the policy and procedural changes that will affect their daily work and to manage 
stakeholders’ expectations of FMR benefits. The terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 24 months, from September 2003 to August 
2005. The lead consultant, to be assisted by a local counterpart to be provided by the Ministry of 
Finance  and  Planning,  will  be  responsible  for  coordinating  the  work  of  all  members.  The 
consultants will contribute, as appropriate, to the progress and final reports to be prepared by 
the lead consultant. Each consultant, however, will prepare his/her final report on specific 
achievements  and  lessons  learned  under  the  TA,  covering  his/her  particular  area  of 
expertise/responsibility.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of US$460,000 on a grant basis 
to the Government of the Fiji Islands for Strengthening Public Sector Financial Governance, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope and Work Program 
1.  The key purpose of the technical assistance (TA) is to provide the public sector financial 
management  expertise  required  to  assist  the  Government  in  the  review  of  the  relevant 
legislation, in particular the suspended Public Finance Management Act (PFMA) of 1999, to 
initiate planning for the implementation of the revised PFMA and the transfer of knowledge and 
skills to local counterparts to ensure no long-term reliance on foreign experts. The TA aims to 
institutionalize an acceptable level of support in budgeting and financial management (including 
some knowledge of the selected financial software system) to ensure that staff understand the 
practical requirements of the revised PFMA, the linkages between output/performance-based 
budgeting and reporting, financial devolution, and managerial accountability. 
2.  The consultants engaged under the TA will undertake on-the-job training of local staff in 
the requirements of output/performance-based public finance management as applied in the Fiji 
Islands and as incorporated into the new financial management information system (FMIS) that 
will support the budgeting, accounting, reporting, and performance monitoring activities under 
the performance-oriented management system. As the implementation of the revised PFMA will 
be phased over a minimum of 3 years, and given that the Fiji Islands has already introduced a 
partial medium-term expenditure framework and a performance management system for senior 
public servants, a pilot implementation of output/performance budgeting is not planned at this 
stage. It is however important that transitional arrangements be carefully planned to enable full 
implementation at the end of the period. 
 
B.   Terms of Reference for International Consultants 
 
1.  Public Sector Financial Management Specialist/ Lead Consultant  
(12 person-months) 
 
3.  This person will 
 
(i)  have extensive experience in public sector accounting and budgeting especially 
under an output/performance-based system; the person is expected to provide 
technical  leadership  in  applying  public  expenditure  management  and 
output/performance-based management principles and practices to suit the Fiji 
Islands’ circumstances; 
(ii)  have extensive experience in public sector reform policy development as to the 
relationship  among  public  expenditure  management,  budgeting,  financial 
management, and the role of ministers and central agencies vis-à-vis operational 
agencies and their ministers; 
(iii)  lead  a  small  work  group  to  review  various  pieces  of  reform  legislation  and 
recommend a revised scope of the financial management legislation and actions 
to adequately support the Government’s policy priorities in the short to medium 
term; 
(iv)  be responsible for the preparation of a realistic and achievable implementation 
plan  that  takes  into  account  government  policy  preferences  in  term  of  risk 
management, current skills and capacity, training requirements, and available 
resources to support the implementation; 
(v)  provide  the  necessary  expertise  to  establish,  support,  and  advise  the 
implementation steering committee, especially in the early stages, and provide

responsibility for a successful implementation; 
(vi)  with assistance of the financial management training specialist and staff of the 
selected local education institution, be responsible for the technical content and 
oversee  the  preparation  of  the  training  materials  and  timetable  to  ensure 
successful implementation of the revised PFMA; 
(vii)  liaise with the software supplier to ensure that the training program supports the 
introduction of the new FMIS, which should meet the requirements of the revised 
PFMA; 
(viii)  provide  technical  advice  to  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Planning  staff  in  the 
preparation  of  budgeting,  accounting,  and  reporting  instructions  needed  to 
support departmental staff in implementing the new regime of financial devolution 
and accountability; 
(ix)  advise and assist the implementation steering committee in writing the terms of 
reference for the recruitment of domestic consultants, and liaise with the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for the timely recruitment of short-term consultants as 
needed; 
(x)  oversee the work of all consulting team members to ensure achievement of 
milestones established in the implementation plan; oversee and participate in the 
initial training sessions to departmental staff;  
(xi)  advise and assist the implementation steering committee in the preparation of the 
communication strategy and activities; and 
(xii)  provide ad hoc advice to the designated local counterpart as requested. 
 
4.  The consultant is responsible for preparing brief progress reports to the implementation 
steering committee and ADB indicating achievement since the last report and future actions 
compared with the implementation plan, and for liaising with ADB for the recruitment of short-
term consultants to be funded under the TA. Three months before the end of the contract, the 
consultant will prepare a draft final report setting out milestones achieved to date, what remains 
to be done, and an assessment of the capability of the local staff to undertake the tasks. The 
report  will  be  discussed  with  ADB  and  the  Government  prior  to  its  finalization  upon  the 
completion of the contract. The consultant will need to cooperate with consultants from other 
external aid agencies (e.g., Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre, Australian Agency for 
International Development) where such cooperation will help achieve the TA objectives. 
 
2.  Financial Management Training Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
5.  It is likely that a short-term specialist will be necessary to supplement the expertise 
required in the second phase of the TA. The person should have a proven record of successful 
preparation  of  training  materials  and  delivery  of  training  workshops  in  public  financial 
management for finance staff and nonfinance managers. 
 
6.  The specialist will have knowledge and practical experience in public sector budgeting 
including  public  expenditure  management,  accounting,  and  financial  reporting  under 
output/performance-based public resource management. 
 
7.  The specialist will work closely with and support the lead consultant of the TA to achieve 
a successful training program (including at the minimum the modules identified in Output item 7 
of  the  TA  logical  framework,  Appendix  1)  and  the  transfer  of  skills  to  local  counterparts, 
including staff of the selected local education institution, to ensure ongoing training in the future.

  3.  Systems Accountant (4 person-months) 
 
9.  The systems accountant will have experience in financial software packages that are 
appropriate  for  public  sector  application.  The  person  will  liaise  with  the  selected  software 
supplier to ensure that the installed system incorporates users’ specifications that are consistent 
with the revised PFMA requirements. The systems accountant will thereafter work closely with 
the financial management training specialist and the lead consultant to develop a users’ training 
program,  in  conjunction  with  the  software  supplier,  to  ensure  that  users  understand  the 
functionalities of the system and how to use the system for day-to-day operations. 
 
10.  The immediate task of the system accountant will be to (i) assist the Government in 
reviewing the current status of the implementation of SAP software in the Ministry of Finance 
and Planning; (ii) assist in assessing the functionalities and capacity of SAP and other financial 
software to meet the likely new Financial Management Reform (FMR) requirements and the 
potential to continually support accounting and reporting requirements during the transitional 
period; (iii) recommend the way forward on the selection and implementation of a suitable 
software, given the revised PFMA requirements; and (iv) assist in the development of the users’ 
specifications of the new system as appropriate. 
 
C.  Terms of Reference for Domestic Consultants 
 
1.  Communication Consultant  
 
11.  The  communication consultant  will  be  an  integral  member  of  the  team  and  will,  in 
coordination with the lead consultant and other team members 
 
(i)  formulate  a  consultative  process  and  public  information  campaign  to  inform 
stakeholders, including public servants, the private sector, and civil society, of the 
objectives of the financial management reform, the benefits expected, and major 
elements and timing of FMR; 
(ii)  conduct the information sessions with participation of other team members as 
necessary; 
(iii)  under the direction of the lead consultant (or the local counterpart), arrange 
briefing  and  training  sessions  for  public  servants  as  FMR  implementation 
progresses; 
(iv)  coordinate  feedback  from  participants  of  the  information/briefing  sessions  to 
ensure the FMR project takes account of comments as appropriate; 
(v)  provide input to the lead consultant to enable the preparation of reports required 
by the steering committee and ADB; and 
(vi)  prepare ad hoc reports to the steering committee and ADB on specific aspects of 
the communication strategy, its effectiveness, and improvements. 
 
2.  Local Education Institution 
12.  A  specialist  from  the  local  education  institution  is  expected  to  work  with  the  lead 
consultant and the financial management training specialist in developing the training program 
and materials: the international consultants will advise on the technical content of the program, 
while the local education specialist will ensure that the training materials observe standards in

the preparation of educational materials and are appropriate to the existing level of education 
and skills of the public service. In addition it is critical that the education specialist has some 
background in financial management to facilitate the transfer of technical knowledge (i.e., public 
sector financial management) from the international consultants so as to ensure sustainability of 
the training program after the completion of the TA.    
 
13.  Specific tasks of the education specialist include  
 
(i)  assessing the existing skill base and adequacy of current resources in public 
expenditure and financial management in public sector agencies; 
(ii)  assisting the international consultants in developing of the scope and content of 
the training program in support of the FMR implementation, and ensuring that the 
training materials observe the educational standards appropriate for this type of 
training;  
(iii)  from (i) and (ii) above, preparing a training needs analysis for discussion with 
other  team  members,  culminating  in  a  training  program  and  timetable  for 
approval by the steering committee; 
(iv)  carrying  out  the  initial  training  program  in  conjunction  with  the  international 
consultants with a view to taking over the responsibility after the completion of 
the TA; 
(v)  coordinating feedback from course participants on the training program to make 
sure that the courses are updated to reflect financial management practices and 
remain relevant to the needs of the Fiji public sector; and 
(vi)  providing input to the lead consultant to enable the preparation of reports to the 
steering committee and ADB. 
 
14.  The Government will finance the domestic consultants. It is expected that the lead 
consultant will assist the steering committee in the development of detailed terms of reference 
and  the  selection  process.  The  domestic  consultants  will  be  selected  in  accordance  with 
arrangements satisfactory to the ADB for the engagements of domestic consultants, and will be 
responsible to the steering committee through the committee’s secretariat.
